Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the mother should purchase it
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Story: It’s midnight when my phone buzzes, jolting me from a restless sleep. My friend’s name flashes on the screen, and I answer to the sound of her sobs. She barely manages to say her brother’s name before dissolving into tears. I sit up, heart pounding, trying to offer soothing words, but my mind is racing. Just hours ago, my son had fallen asleep clutching a dog-eared Nintendo catalog, his eyes shining with hope. I’d promised him I’d buy it soon, but the bills on the kitchen table say otherwise. I know he’s counting on me to keep my word, to make his birthday special, but every dollar feels stretched thin. Now, my friend needs me—really needs me—to listen, to be present, to help her through the night. I want to give her my full attention, but guilt gnaws at me. I can’t stop thinking about my son’s expectant face, the promise I made, and the money I don’t have. My friend’s pain is raw and immediate, but so is the pressure to provide for my family. I clutch the phone, torn between two worlds, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
